content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act" or the "SECURE Act." Legal recourse for consumers is provided. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow for injunctive relief in addition to other remedies. Courts may award injunctive relief to ensure compliance with the Act's requirements for consumers, with the prevailing party potentially receiving costs and attorney fees. Courts may award injunctive relief to ensure compliance with the Act's requirements for consumers, with the prevailing party potentially receiving costs and attorney fees. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow for injunctive relief and enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission for negligent, willful, or knowing violations. Prevailing parties may receive costs and attorney fees. Increased requirements for consumer reporting agencies and furnishers of information. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for documentation provided by consumers, enhancing requirements for consumer reporting agencies and information furnishers. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for documentation provided by consumers, enhancing requirements for consumer reporting agencies and information furnishers by inserting relevant information, including all documentation, in various subsections. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for documentation provided by consumers and enhance requirements for consumer reporting agencies by considering all relevant information, including documentation, in disputes. The Bureau will provide reports on disputes received by agencies at appropriate intervals and to relevant parties. The Bureau will prescribe rules for gathering information on disputes received by consumer reporting agencies, including the type, format, and frequency of information to be provided. Accuracy compliance procedures under the Fair Credit Reporting Act are amended to ensure the accuracy of reports. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require consumer reporting agencies to follow reasonable procedures to ensure the accuracy of consumer reports. The Bureau will issue a proposed rule within a year to establish these procedures. The Bureau will consider requiring the matching of specific consumer information to improve the accuracy of consumer reports, including first and last name, date of birth, full social security number, and any other relevant details. The Bureau aims to enhance the accuracy of consumer reports by requiring specific consumer information matching. Amendments are made to the Fair Credit Reporting Act regarding responsibilities of furnishers of information and disclosures to consumers. Amendments to the Fair Credit Reporting Act require furnishers of information to provide specific consumer details for accurate consumer reports. This includes supplying consumers with a widely distributed credit score for credit transactions. Amendments to the Fair Credit Reporting Act require furnishers to provide consumers with a widely distributed credit score for credit transactions. Additionally, a credit score must be provided free of charge to the consumer upon request in connection with a free annual consumer report. Amendments to the Fair Credit Reporting Act include changes to notification requirements for adverse information and offer of credit on less favorable terms. Subsection (g)(1) is modified by striking subparagraph (C) and redesignating subparagraphs (D) through (G). Additionally, section 612 is amended to provide free disclosure after notice of adverse action or offer of credit on less favorable terms within 14 days. The Fair Credit Reporting Act has been amended to include changes in notification requirements for adverse information and credit offers on less favorable terms. Additionally, the Act requires notification and disclosure requirements for consumer reports as described in paragraph (1) and subsequent submissions of negative information. The Bureau is tasked with defining certain disclosure requirements through a proposed rule within one year of the Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act's enactment. The Bureau will publish a proposed rule to implement disclosure requirements under section 612(b) of the Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act. Considerations include providing consumers with information to understand reasons for adverse actions or less favorable credit terms, while ensuring consumer privacy. SEC. 4. REGULATORY REFORM. Section 621 of the Federal Credit Reporting Act is amended to establish 3 publicly available registries of consumer reporting agencies, including nationwide consumer reporting agencies, nationwide specialty consumer reporting agencies, and other consumer reporting agencies. All consumer reporting agencies must register. All consumer reporting agencies defined in section 603(f) must register with one of the registries established by the Bureau within a specified timeframe. SEC. 5. STUDY OF A PUBLIC CREDIT REPORTING SYSTEM. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on international credit systems, government-administered consumer credit reporting systems, accuracy of existing systems, feasibility of a national system, consumer benefits, and costs. Findings will be published within 18 months. The Comptroller General of the United States will publish findings on the government-administered consumer credit reporting system within 18 months of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE: The provisions of this Act and its amendments will take effect 6 months after enactment.
